Name: F-Cartes
Description:
F-Cartes is a game for 2 to 10 people that simulates Formula On races with cards.

There are four type of cards: Events, spaces, cars, and teams

The game may by played in 6, 12 or 24 rounds.

Name: A Game of Games
Description:
So, you think you know games?  You are reading the latest magazines, going to the most recent conventions, and perusing the Boardgame Geek?  then perhaps you and a partner are ready to take on your knowledgeable opponents at A Game of Games as teams compete to guess titles of games before their learned companions.

The game is similar to Password, but players try to clue the names of games instead of English words, and there are a few additional scoring opportunities.

Name: Lock 'n Load Tactical: Dark July 43
Description:
Lock ’n Load Tactical Dark July Second Edition. depicts the brutal battles fought west of Prochorovka between July 9th and 12th, 1943, during the epic Battle of Kursk.

Four 11” x 17” non-geomorphic maps fit together to form an immense 22” x 34” historical battlefield, covering the famed Hill 252.2, the Soviet trenches to the east, and the Oktiabrski State Farm to the north. Six scenarios—five on the historical map—will test your tactical acumen as either the determined Soviet defenders of the Motherland or the brazen 1st SS Panzergrenadier Division Leibstandarte Adolf Hitler (LAH). Dark July includes rules for hand-held RPG-43 anti-tank grenades, anti-tank mines and ditches, low wheat, tank emplacements, roadblocks, and much more.

Dark July is an expansion module; to play it you will need either Lock 'n Load Tactical: Heroes of the Motherland or Lock 'n Load: Band of Heroes with Lock 'n Load: Not One Step Back.

UPDATE: All of our manuals and guides can be Downloaded, Viewed, and even printed right from our LnLP Online Library: We now have an Online Library of all, well almost all of our manuals.  We add some every few weeks.  You can find all the LnLT manuals at the link below.
Families: Players: Games with expansions that add solo play

Name: Erosion
Description:
Each player tries to erode their mountain and generate the most amount of sediment in their delta. Players erode their mountains with the processes they successfully bid on and acquire. The sediment supplied to the delta becomes the coinage used in the bidding process. Mountains uplift 1,500 meters per turn until one player reaches 8,000 meters, or until the "Active Uplift Shutdown" event card is drawn. Then, it's a race to see who can erode their mountain away the fastest. When a player successfully erodes their mountain, the game ends. The winner is the player with the most sediment in their delta, after subtracting any sediment that remains in their mountain.

To the play the game, you need to print out a copy of the rules, the bidding row, the game cards (the card types include event, process, mountain front, and mountain type), and enough game boards for the number of players that will play. A cool rock and a cup to hold the sediment is also needed. You will also need to buy a couple boxes of Jujubees (you can eat them while you play), as they are the "sediment" used in the game.

The designer recommended printing the game materials (except the rules) in color, on 11" x 17" cardstock. To make the game, the designer recommended using a paper cutter, a glue stick, scissors (for minor clean up), and scotch tape.

The "Erosion" v. 1.0 ZIP file was available for download as of May 9, 2008 at the designer's former webpage

The files have been unavailable since Sierra Madre Games announced that they were publishing a revised version of Erosion in 2009.

Name: Chinesenspiel
Description: Chinesenspiel (meaning "Chinese game") is a 19th century German game of the Pachisi family, but simplified so there is only one piece per player.  The board layout is similar to the Korean game Yut Nori.

Name: Red Christmas: Moscow Counteroffensive
Description:
Red Christmas-the CSIR and the Moscow Counteroffensive, December 22-30, 1941, brings the ASL enthusiast directly into the path of a combined-arms Red Army assault.  Mixed German and Italian forces try and stave off disaster on the Eastern Front in a series of pitched battles depicted in the module's scenarios.

Historical battlefield maps are what CH is all about and Red Christmas continues that tradition with two new historical maps depicting the villages of Orlovo Ivanovka and Novo Orlovka, situated directly in the path of Stalin's Moscow counteroffensive.

This is not a complete game! Ownership of Beyond Valor is required to use this product.  Ownership of Hollow Legions is NOT required.  Variant 'Berlin Style' MMC, SMC, SW, and needed Guns are provided for Italian combatants.

Contents: 6 scenarios, 2 historical maps, variant special rules, and die cut color counters.

Expands:

    Advanced Squad Leader
    Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1

Name: STORM Operação Tempestade
Description: This is a game made in Portugal in 1991 by Fanabri that simulates operation Desert Storm .

Name: Bimmelkette
Description:
Bimmelkette
Bell-Ringing Chain (English translation)

By throwing dice players collect wooden beads and wooden animals as indicated on their task cards, comparing their colors and threading them on a colored shoestring with a bell tied in the middle.

The players try to complete their chain in the right order to match the picture by means of luck and manual dexterity.

Dice with colored circles are used to determine whether the player can thread a certain color or collect a bead or animal from the box, depending upon the variation played.

Three games variations are outlined:  "grundspiel" or basic;  "mischfarben" or blended colors; and "symmetrie" or symmetry.

The player who is first to right the bell of his/her completely threaded and correctly ordered chain is the winner.

Name: Dice GOLF Game
Description: AIM : To complete 9 or 18 holes , using the dice to make your way around the course, with the lowest score possible (to play 18 holes, turn around at hole 9 and proceed back to hole 1 ) .

Name: It Was a Dark and Stormy Night
Description:
Players or teams move their markers around a board according to the roll of a die. The spaces on the board are 12 categories of literature. A marker lands on a category, the first few lines from a work in that category are read, and the player with that marker tries to identify the work. The first player or team to identify eight works wins.

Equipment
» Game board
» 4 player pawns
» 30 book tokens
» 12 categories of clue cards with divider cards
» Die

Name: Be-Rhymed!
Description:
The symbol on the die determines whether a player will speak his clues, act out his clues, or draw his clues. He draws a card and, using only the specified type of clue, attempts to get his teammates to guess the two rhyming but unrelated words (eg, match catch) that are written on the card next to the symbol that matches the symbol on the die.
Run through as many cards as the two-minute timer permits.
Score one point for each spoken rhyme and two points for each acted out or drawn rhyme.

Name: Piratspelet
Description:
A game similar to (but not identical to) Ludo, where the players race to be first to the treasure in the middle of the board.

2-4 players can play, taking turns. Each have three pieces, moving by rolls of a die along interconnected paths that lead to the treasure. The paths are organized in three distinctive levels with paths between them. The players can knock out other player's pieces by landing on them so they start over (just like in Ludo). The paths include special spots, including green spots (skip three turns), red spots (slide down to an earlier path, like in Snakes&Ladders) and blue spots (entrance to the next level).

It is clearly of german origin since it is designed by Rolf Kauka, a famous german cartoonist. German publications and name are unknown. A swedish low-cost version was sold in Sweden in the 1970's, most likely produced by Klee. Although Klee is not printed on the game, Klee made other games in identical boxes with similar part numbers.

The game is mostly known in Sweden through a famous comedy sketch from the late 60's, with four adults trying to socialize by playing the game but the play quickly turns into bickering. This makes the game particularly interesting as a game that everybody knows about but few have played.

Contents:
1 Boardgame
12 playing pieces 4x3 
1 dice

Name: Resopol
Description:
Welcome to the Hotel business. You will be the manager of a couple of hotels in Sweden. Have you what it takes and the skills to be a manager? See your empire grow and be the first to get 5 million and win this game.

Contents:
1 Boardgame
2 dice
6 piccolo pieces
6 plastic top in different colors
128 cards
Green and red hotels 
Money
Rules

Name: Scooby-Doo och monstret
Description:
Your job is to reveal the monster in the castle. You will start at the Mystery Machine. In the beginning you have two clues that will help catch the monster. The first player to reveal the monster will win the game.

Contents:
1 board game
5 playing pieces
5 clues
14 monster cards
1 dice
rules

Name: Globalny konflikt
Description: Risk clone with a solid, pretty board and cardboard tokens for armies. The board's changed a bit and the rules for conflict resolution are original.

Name: Need for Speed Trading Card Game
Description:
Every Car you race will have its own combination of attributes in the areas of acceleration, handling and top speed. These strengths and weaknesses will be tested when you are forced to complete Driving Tests, either as you pass through certain Checkpoints on the Track, or from Events or Maneuvers cards played by your opponents. Fail the test and depending on the card, you’ll need to sacrifice an Upgrade from your Car.

Cars are moving on the Track built from cards and face different combinations of challenges from Checkpoints on the cards.

Theme Decks available are: Beach Blitz, Canyon Rush and Downtown Dash.

Name: Napoleon 1796-1800
Description:
Strategic-operational scale wargame about Italian campaigns of Bonaparte in 1796-1800.

Game scale:
1 counter = army/corps/division or commander
1 turn = 2 days

Name: Kamchatka
Description:
INTRO
Kamchatka (yes, THAT Kamchatka), somehow, has escaped the damage brought by man’s over development of our globe. To this day it remains one of the great unspoiled wildernesses on the planet and one of the most rugged places on the Earth.  Located on the Pacific’s Ring of Fire, Kamchatka holds some of the world’s most beautiful active volcanoes. Add to that the earthquakes, mudslides, flooding, and avalanches and it is easy to see why Kamchatka is literally a force of nature.

The fauna is just as imposing: Giant roc-like eagles reign from above (seriously, google Stellar’s Eagles-these things are unreal!); huge sockeye salmon are plentiful in the many rivers and waterways; walrus and seals live and breed along the shores; herds of reindeer number in the thousands; and there is a greater density of giant grizzly bear in Kamchatka than anywhere else in the world.

GAME
In Kamchatka you must fight to survive.  Time stands still here: You play an indigenous hunter hundreds—even thousands—of years ago surrounded by Kamchatka’s frigid seas, great rivers, dense forests, and snowcapped volcanic mountains.  Your village depends on you and your small hunting party to hunt, trap, and trade in order to search out the resources they need.  You will risk your life on this journey through Kamchatka’s harsh bush and in its treacherous seas to bring back the required resources to your villagers.

Kamchatka is designed to play solitaire or for 2 to 4 players.

Name: Budapeszt 1945
Description:
In January 1945 Germans made last offensive in WWII trying to de-blockade Budapest in Hungary.

The game uses rules of the "WB95" (Great Battles 1939-1945) system designed for dealing with large battles of World War II. Counters represent regiments (Germans) or divisions (Russians), one hex represents about 2500m, one turn represents one day.

Name: Don Mattingly's Baseball
Description:
A simple roll dice and guess result to score points.

Contents:
1 felt Baseball field
1 bat
3 runner markers (blue)
4 scoring markers (2 white, 2 red)
3 umpire markers (blue)
2 pitching dice
4 hit dice

The batter takes the bat and places it over any three box sections of the batting box. The bat is laid across, up and down or diagonally on the boxes. It should cover 3 squares.
The pitcher roll the two pitching dice to determine where the pitch went.
If the bat is not in the section of the pitch, the batter is out, otherwise the ball is hit and the batter rolls the four hit dice to see what type of hit he has gotten.
A roll of one ball equals a single, two balls are a double, three a triple and four balls are a home run.

The Sport Dice is a collection of sport, there are Basketball, Football, Boxing and Golf.

Name: Magnetic Space-Venture
Description:
A very simple roll-and-move game played with magnetic pawns on a small 'travel' gameboard. Players roll to move, check to see if they landed on a space with instructions and then resolve the instructions, if any.

No decisions made by any player.

Name: Spanish Fury: Hell on the Eastern Front
Description:
Spanish Fury-Hell on the Eastern Front brings the ASL enthusiast to the chaos of the Eastern Front during late 1941 as Axis satellite troops attempt to stave off a resurgent Red Army.

Historical battlefield maps are what CH is all about and Spanish Fury continues that tradition with two new maps, including a long, unique riverside of the Vulkhov River, with two villages, Russa and Sitno, to fight for, and contest the terrain between.

This is not a complete game! Ownership of Beyond Valor is required to use this product.  A set of new MMC counters depicting the 250th 'Blau' Division, complete with accurate shoulder patch emblems, are included, along with Sturmboot, Wagon and guns, a total of 192 color die cut counters!

Contains: 8 scenarios, 2 maps, variant special rules, and 192 die cut color counters.

Expands:

    Advanced Squad Leader and Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1 (both required)

Name: Yhdistä sana ja kuva
Description: An educational domino-like game with puzzle-like pieces for children. All pieces include a word and a picture; they can be placed next to each other only if the two match.

Name: Kiekko GaMes
Description: A Finnish hockey trivia game with questions about the following leagues and tournaments: SM-liiga, I-divisioona, NHL, IHWC, Canada Cup, Olympic Games, women's SM-liiga and hockey rules. By answering questions correctly one can place player cards (with real Finnish player names) to the rink, whereas wrong answers lead to the penalty box.

Name: Viisasten kivi
Description:
"A trivia quiz for the young and young at heart"

Designed by the same core team of Otila & Lindfors, this is a sort of companion game to Viisasten Kokous, but supposedly aimed at the younger crowd; which in this case means that this is a trivia game on the same general level of difficulty as Trivial Pursuit etc., compared to Viisasten Kokous which is extremely challenging to the average trivia player. The games were likely published concurrently (1987) or quite close apart, which make them among the last publications of Paletti.

The general idea of the game is to try and climb the rock on which the philosopher's stone (Viisasten Kivi) lies; this happens by picking cards and answering the questions correctly to move three spaces ahead, up to a maximum of two cards per player turn. Unlike usual trivia games, this is a bit more casual in that mixed in with the question cards are also event cards which work like event cards in a typical roll-and-move game ie. pass a turn, move ahead two, move back one etc., with flavor text. There are also blank cards which can either be used to make house questions or to be optionally mixed in the deck too, in this case a blank card simply means "pass the turn".

Includes 150 cards; 100 question cards with 5 questions each, 25 event cards and 25 blanks, in three decks with tuckboxes.

Name: Valencia
Description:
This one is my first game design and was a finalist in the Hippodice competition.  For those having the desire, time and energy to put it all together, the files are here for print and play.  You will need to supply money.

A summary of the idea:

The Game
You have been hired to go to the island of Valencia and acquire crystals before your opponents.  You will meet the various personalities that make up the island and must bribe, steal or buy to accomplish your mission.  However, others will be attempting to do the same.  So, be smart.  First you must try to earn the ear of the council person to tell you where the best deal in town can be found.  Only the highest bidder will get the location known only to them.  Being a smart treasure seeker, you may follow quietly and search the area around where the high bidder goes.  Unfortunately for everyone, people only have a limited number of crystals.  Once a site has been visited, no one may visit again.

Name: Fall nicht vom Hocker
Description:
Content:
board, 4 pawns in 4 colors, 1 number die, 1 color die

Each player tries to get opponents to fall off of the stool without falling off of the stool themselves.

Name: Bunte Reihe
Description:
Content:
tiles with the value 1-6 or different colors, 1 die with numbers, 1 die with colors

The players are landscape planners. They have tiles to get rid of them and to form a landscape with them.

The first player to get rid of his plates wins.

Name: Bienenkorb
Description:
Content: board, 1 die, 4 pawns in 4 colors

The honey bees collect honey in order to bring it to the bee queen. Each of them like to be the fastest.

Name: Bamse 5:an
Description:
Children´s game featuring Swedish cartoon bear Bamse and his friends. The 56 cards are evenly distributed between players. In order, each player turns up the top card of his/her deck and plays it on the table. Each card features 1, 2, 3 or 4 pictures of one of the characters. When a player´s card adds the fifth picture of the same character to the table, that player picks up all the cards from the table and adds them to the bottom of his deck. Then the next player plays his top card.

As players lose their last card they are eliminated form play. The winner is the last player with cards remaining.

A very simple card game without decision making, much like War and similar games.

Contents
56 cards
2 additional cards with rules

Name: Quiz & Co. Europa
Description:
Content: 31 cards with 8 questions and answers each, packed together in a fan

The game can be played with questioning and answering by points. 10 points are the final goal, or it can also be played by time. Who has the most points after a certain time wins.

The "Reise"-Edition (traveling) has questions about the European states.

Name: Near vs Normal Chess
Description:
Near vs Normal Chess pits pieces following Near Chess rules against those following normal chess rules.  Either black or white side can play with the Near Chess rules, while the other side plays with regular chess rules.  Players need to decide at the start of the game which pawn promotion and win conditions are used (Near or normal chess rules).

People are encouraged to either download the rules here or read the rules on the Chess Variants website:
http://www.chessvariants.org/index/msdisplay.php?itemid=MSnearvsnormalch

Name: Playoff
Description:
Playoff is a fast paced discard game similar to Crazy Eights.    It is played on a mat and uses a special deck of cards.

Play a card that matches the suit or value of the previous played card.  If a player is unable to do so, cards must be drawn until there is a legal play, and the player pays one chip to the pot for each card drawn.

The eights in the deck are replaced by 'star' cards, which allows players to change suit and collect the current pot.  The player with the most chips wins.

In 1976 a version featuring Jack Klugman and Tony Randall, The Odd Couple, was published, with Klugman and Randall cards in the deck.

Name: Monopoly: Augsburg
Description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Augsburg, in Germany.

Name: Belly Up
Description:
A variation of the Monopoly-style investment game. The goal: to become the wealthiest player by purchasing investments and collecting investment returns from other players.

Game equipment includes a game board, dice, six playing pieces, play money, "ownership markers", "investment broker" charts, and economy / world affair cards.

Players roll two dice to move around the board. Actions are dependent on where the player lands and can include buying or selling different types of investments, doubling your investment, trading in your automobile, drawing a card and following the instructions, or following other instructions on the board.

If a player runs out of funds and is unable to meet the obligations of any creditor, they have gone "belly up." The last player left is the winner.

Name: Deep Blue Death
Description:
Deep Blue Death is a simple "beer & pretzels" wargame for two players. Each player controls a fleet of submarines and decoys by issuing a limited number of orders each turn. Players must manage their resources carefully to win. Victory conditions depend on the scenario.

The PDF includes rules, counters, scenarios and a map.

From the publisher's website:
In the year 2020 mankind finds themselves with little but submarines after a terrorist attack. Use your sonar to distinguish between subs and decoys. Fire rocket powered torpedoes through the water at 200 miles per hour! Dodge enemy torpedoes with noisemakers or evasive maneuvers. But manage your resources carefully; when you’re out of torpedoes, you’re just a target.

Name: Monopoly: Flemish Edition
Description:
This is a Flemish version of the Monopoly Game.  The game was published bij deSka from Brussels.  Gameplay is the same as the original Monopoly.

Places on the board:
Go: Start
Free Parking: Vrij Parkeren
Gaol: Gevangenis
Go To Gaol: Naar De Gevangenis
Income Tax: Inkomsten Belasting
Luxury Tax: Extra Belasting
Chance: Kans
Community Chest: Algemeen Fonds
Indigo: Leuven, Dieststraat / Mechelen, Bruul
Gray: Leuven, Bondgenotenlaan / Turnhout, Gasthuisstraat / Turnhout, Leopoldstraat
Purple: Aalst, Lange Zoutstraat / Brugge, Vlamingenstraat / Knokke, Kustlaan
Orange: Brugge, Steenstraat / Oostende, Kapellestraat / Kortrijk, Rijselstraat
Red: Tienen, Leuvensestraat / Gent, Kortrijksestraat / Hasselt, Grote Markt
Yellow: Antwerpen, Groenplaats / Brussel, Lakenstraat / Gent, Veldstraat
Green: Antwerpen, Huidevettersstraat / Gent, Vlaanderenstraat, Hasselt, Demersstraat
Blue: Antwerpen Meir, Brussel Nieuwstraat
Railway Stations (Stations): Noordstation, Centraal Station, Buurtspoorwegen, Zuidstation
Utilities: Electriciteitscentraal, Waterdienst

Name: Inspeaquence
Description:
From the rules:
"If you can speak in sequence you can play INSPEAQUENCE!
Two teams of up to five players each have 60 seconds in which to create sentence style clues to the six words on the INSPEAQUENCE cards.
There is, however, a twist: each player can only say one word on their turn.  And they have to make sense while speaking in sequence - hence the name of the game!
The aim of the game:
Each word correctly guessed gains that team a point-ball.  To win, simply be the first team to fill up your scoring arrow with the balls!"

There are different versions explained in the rules for if 2 to 5 players or 6 to 10 players are playing.

Name: Moon Rocket Express
Description: Thrilling adventure among the planets. An educational game designed to provide hours of thrilling entertainment for young astronauts while they become acquainted with this new and exciting race through space.

Name: Besser-Esser
Description:
From the rules:
Do you know the Taster-lots family? You don't?! No wonder; they come from a very distant planet and they touched down on earth by accident. When they visit a supermarket they are overwhelmed by the tons of food because on their planet there is only pink striped slimy sea grass. So they start tasting everything: cheese, chocolate, butter, plums, frozen pizza,
spinach, potato chips, canned fish, raspberry marmalade…
Suddenly their faces go all funny with squares. “I feel really sick!” moans Tim Taster-lots. “I have eaten so much I can't move”, complains Daddy Taster-lots. They all know they have eaten too much. But what should they have eaten and how? Can you help?

Throughout the game you collect the foodstuff that your body needs during the day. Doing so, you should collect neither too much nor too little foodstuff. The food pyramid printed on your stamp sheet shows how much and which foods you should eat during the day. Each little box of the pyramid corresponds to one portion of the foodstuff shown.
Example: Your body needs 4 portions of fruit and vegetables while you should only eat 1 portion of sweets (a portion is as much as fits in your hand).
The aim of the game is to be the first to have checked all the boxes on your nutritional sheet with a stamp.

Name: Katzenbande
Description:
The aim of the game is to collect the most fish.

You have to try to gather kitten gangs! Whoever manages to gather either three identical cats or any three cats on the same colored background, receives a fish as a reward.

Uncover any card and place it in front of you. One by one all players uncover a card to try to collect a kitten gang of three identical cats or any three cats on the same colored background.

-There can never be more than three cards in front of you. When it's your turn and you already have three cards, you have to return one of them face up to the center of the table and only then can you uncover a new card.

-Instead of uncovering a hidden card you can also take a card from the ones face-up in the center, except for the one you just placed there.

Name: Royal Netherlands Navy
Description:
A 23-page supplement adding the Royal Netherlands Navy (RNN) and ABDA ships to General Quarters (Third Edition). It includes the RNN Surface Combat Charts, ship logs for both RNN and ABDA, formation cards for Dutch aircraft and three scenarios. There's also an article about a hypothetical British battle cruiser in Dutch service.

The scenarios are:


     Brawl in the Badung Strait (ABDA vs. IJN 1942)
     Battle of Borneo (RNN vs. IJN 1942, what-if)
     Running the Gauntlet (RNN vs. IJN 1942, what-if)


The supplement is only available as an electronic document (PDF).

Expands:

    General Quarters (Third Edition)
Families: Series: GQ III Decisions at Sea (Old Dominion GameWorks)

Name: American War of Independence Scenarios 2
Description:
Includes scenarios, rules amendments and revised playsheets for British Grenadier! miniature rules. The scenarios are:


     Lexington and Concord (1775)
     Trenton (1776)
     Hubbardton: Save the Guns! (1777)
     Germantown: Washington's Attack (1777)
     Monmouth Courthouse: The Morning Action (1778)
     Newport: Pigot's Attack (1778)
     Savannah (1779)
     Spencer's Ordinary (1781)
     Eutaw Springs: The South's Bloody Finale (1781)
     Gloucester Point (hypothetical 1781)


48 pages + 4 page card playsheet

Expands:

    British Grenadier! Gaming the Wars for America 1775-1783

Name: American War of Independence Scenarios 1
Description:
A selection of scenarios for British Grenadier! miniature wargame rules. Follows a format similar to the scenario books published for General de Brigade.

The scenarios included are:


     White Plains (1776)
     Oriskany: Twilight of the Iroquois (1777)
     Brandywine: Cornwallis's Attack (1777)
     Brandywine: Knyphausen's Battle (1777)
     Bemis Heights (Second Saratoga) (1777)
     Monmouth: Washington Saves the Day (1778)
     La Vigie: France's Bunker Hill (1778)
     Camden (1780)
     Hannah's Cowpens (1781)
     Hobkirk's Hill (1781)


Also included are rules addenda, a colour insert with wargaming flags and a revised playsheet.
48 pages + 4 page card playsheet

Expands:

    British Grenadier! Gaming the Wars for America 1775-1783

Name: Proletarians, To Horse!
Description:
Army lists and rules amendments for Square Bashing 1914-1918 miniature rules to include battles of the Russian Civil War. A total of 26 different army lists is included. Additional rules include things like propaganda offensives and gunboats.

Expands:

    Square Bashing 1914-1918

Name: Uncle Duke's Napoleonette
Description: Napoleonic miniature wargaming at 1:50 scale with 15mm miniatures. The smallest command element is a Division, miniatures are organized into Regiments. The rules include orders of battle for the 1809 Austrian campaign.

Name: None Shall Pass!: To Arms!
Description:
Marlburian army lists for use with "None Shall Pass!" wargame rules.

Includes 19 major armies and 22 minor allies. Also has uniform information and a short bibliography.

Expands:

    None Shall Pass! 1688-1717

Name: John Company and the Conquest of India
Description:
A Miniatures Game System for Warfare on the Sub-Continent 1750-1860.

Caters for all miniatures scales with each player controlling roughly a brigade (ca. 50 figure bases). In addition to the wargame rules and army profiles included are a bibliography, scenarios, notes on figure sources and uniform guides.

The scenarios included are:


     The Battle of Assaye (2nd Maratha War, 1803)
     Desperate Measures: Outside Kabul (1st Afghan War, 1841)
     Meeting Engagement at Mudiwal (1st Sikh War, 1845)
     The Relief of Luckhipore (Indian Mutiny, 1857)

Name: Boilers and Breechloaders
Description:
"Being in the Main a Rules System for Miniature Colonial Naval Wargames, ca. 1860-1914 A.D."

Miniature wargame rules for coastal and riverine warfare for the colonial period. Intended to be used with The Sword and the Flame rules but can be played as a "stand alone".
Families: Game: The Sword and the Flame

Name: The Sword in North Africa
Description:
A The Sword And The Flame variant for the French Foreign Legion in North Africa. Includes organization charts for the French and Arab/Bedouin as well as additional rules.

Expands:

    The Sword and the Flame


Expanded by:

    The TSINA Event Deck
Families: Game: The Sword and the Flame

Name: Once Upon a Time in the Western Peninsula
Description: Skirmish wargame rules for the Napoleonic period. Despite the name the game is not merely focused on the Peninsular war. Three scenarios are included.

Name: Guns at Gettysburg Scenarios 1: Heartland – The Battles for Kentucky and The Tennessee
Description:
A selection of scenarios for use with Guns at Gettysburg miniature wargame rules.

The 14 scenarios included are:


     Belmont (1861)
     Logan's Cross Roads (1862)
     Break-Out at Fort Donelson (1862)
     Assault on Fort Donelson (1862)
     Shiloh Church (1862)
     The Hornet's Nest (1862)
     Richmond (1862)
     Munfordville (1862)
     Iuka (1862)
     Battery Robinett (1862)
     Hatchie Bridge (1862)
     Peters Hill (1862)
     Chaplin Hills (1862)
     Invasion! (hypothetical)


Also includes several pages of optional rules for Guns at Gettysburg as well as conversion rules for players of Johnny Reb 2.

Name: General de Brigade: Guns at Gettysburg
Description:
Miniature wargaming rules for American Civil War at 1:20 scale. Based on the General de Brigade system.

Includes two scenarios:


     Antietam: Opening Attack (1862)
     Fredericksburg: Marye's Heights (1862)

Name: Napoleonic Scenarios 3: The Glory Years 1800-1809
Description:
The third volume in a series of Napoleonic scenarios. Designed for General de Brigade wargame rules but generic enough to be usable with other systems.

The scenarios included are:


     Marengo, Part I: The Austrian Breakout (1800)
     Marengo, Part II: The Blooding of the Consular Guard (1800)
     Marengo, Part III: Desaix's Counter Attack (1800)
     Haslach-Jungingen: The Kaiserliks Strike Back (1805)
     Austerlitz, Part I: Attack on the Pratzeberg (1805)
     Austerlitz, Part II: Attack on Stare-Vinohrady (1805)
     Austerlitz, Part III: Attack of the Russian Imperial Guard (1805)
     Auerstädt: Davout Against the Odds (1806)
     Friedland: Ney's Attack (1807)
     Eggmühl: Charles vs. Napoleon (1809)


Also included is an appendix with new rules.

Name: TOP GEAR: The Car's The Star
Description:
The object of the game is to be the first player to reach the finish space at the end of the board.
As you race around the board, a roll of the dice will reveal a little bit more of a car hidden in the clever hide and reveal unit in the centre of the board. The sooner you guess, the higher the possible points; but beware, once a guess has been made, that's it. A wrong guess scores nothing at all. Players have to decide whether to gamble for an early guess, or to hold fire and try to score extra points for having the correct country, body and engine type cards in their hand.  This game includes over 70 large, beautifully photographed classic cars, old and modern. Launched by Top Gear, the hugely successful BBC TV programme.
Game components:
1 x playing board
1 x pack of 72 car cards in full colour
2 x packs of 50 cards comprising;
- Pit Stop, 
- Engine Type, Body Type and Country of Origin.
6 x assorted coloured playing pawns
1 x hide and reveal mechanism
1 x 6-sided standard dice
1 x 6-sided coloured spot dice
1 x rules sheet

Name: Open Season
Description: This is a hunting game that consists of driving out to the hunting lodge, spending 5 days (laps around the lodge area) hunting, then driving back home.  Aside from rolling dice to determine how far to move the game is played primarily with a big composite spinner, which determines the outcome of things like shooting game, luck at the horse track, and playing poker.  Everyone starts with $300 and 5 credentials.  Driving is mostly uneventful except for small financial transactions.  Luck "in the field" is determined by flipping over situation cards when you land on situation space.  Some cards have animals you can try to shoot at, others have bad luck type situations you need to over come by moving or playing a credential card.  Each time a player circumnavigates the lodge (spends one day hunting) they receive a credential and have an opportunity to answer a hunting or safety related question for a cash bonus.

Name: Liskosafari
Description: A Finnish game where players try to collect a set of lizards for the zoo. Two sets of rules are included: the first one is for adults and children over five and the second one for younger children.

Name: Kaktus
Description:
Content: board, 4 x 4 pawns in 4 colors

Bugs surround sheltering the buds which start to bloom. Which bugs are the busiest?

Name: Bafel
Description: Bafel is a Mastermind variant with a few unique twists.  You assign numerical values for five positions, and your opponent can ask for the totals of various positions, until someone can guess all the values.

Name: Monopoly: Bayreuth
Description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Bayreuth, in Germany.

Name: Monopoly: Bielefeld
Description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Bielefeld, in Germany.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Dortmund, in Germany.

Name: Moorhuhn: Zock um dein Leben!
Description:
(Taken from a resale webpage, translated into English)

The well-known "Moorhuhn" computer game turned into a funny dice game. Keep your cool, for the life of the animals depends on the luck of the roll. Caution is advised - if a chicken appears, all points and one of the animals are gone. And every player only has three of them ...

Name: The 15 Greatest Board Games in the World
Description:
15 great games chosen because they are easy to learn, reward multiple playings & appeal to a wide variety of players.... plus, the kids at El Carmelo Elementary liked 'em. :-)

Hoppers / Mini-Hoppers (Halma on a 10x10 and 4x4 board, respectively)
The Game of Y
The Royal Game of Ur
Surround (a Go variant)
Corsaro
Solitaire
Pentominoes
Morris (Nine Men's & Three Men's)
Scatter (Conspirateurs)
Tigers & Goats (Bagh Chal)
Roundabouts (Surakarta)
Fanorona
China Moon
Checkers (Everyday, Giveaway & Super King)
Push Penny Bounce

Name: Hanging Gardens
Description:
King Nebuchadnezzar II has ordered the construction of a grand terraced garden complex, filled with trees and plant beds, to present to his wife as a gift. As royal engineers, the players compete for the king's favor by offering the most beautiful view upon completion of the gardens.

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: MARE NOSTRVM
Description: Mare Nostrum (MARE NOSTRVM) is a Brazilian  game simulating the battles that were fought among Roman and Greek galleys. There is no map. You can play it on the table or floor.

Name: From the Gecko
Description:
If you love puzzles and games you will love From The Gecko™.

From The Gecko™ is a unique speed math game that focuses the player on understanding numbers and making quick decisions. 
Fun for kids of all ages, even grown-ups! Kids will have a blast while learning and laughing. Will you be the first to build your gecko? Great for all ages.

For 2 to 6 players. 
Made in the USA.

Name: Fun With Colors
Description:
Parents and teachers created our products to be effective learning tools, which entertain and educate. The "Fun with™" series of products are designed to stimulate the language and learning skills in young children by introducing two languages seamlessly.

Fun with Colors™ identifies primary and secondary colors, shapes and color association involving familiar objects. It is important to identify objects within each color and ask the child to repeat words and identify objects and colors.

English - Spanish - Box set includes: DVD, workbook and game cards.

Ages 3 and up 
2 to 4 Players.

Name: Fun With Numbers
Description:
Parents and teachers created our products to be effective learning tools, which entertain and educate. The "Fun with™" series of products are designed to stimulate the language and learning skills in young children by introducing two languages seamlessly.

Fun with Numbers™ will help a child learn to count from 1-20 in two languages. The product teaches sequencing and associates a corresponding object with that number. Learning sequencing is an important factor in pre-reading skills.

English - Spanish - Box set includes: DVD, workbook and game cards.

Ages 4 and up 
2 to 4 players.

Name: Da-Di-Do
Description:
"A game of fun for Ages 9 and up,
a must for grades three to five."

An educational game where players roll dice and then add and multiply the pips on the dice.  The totals are entered into the player's scoring chart.  Players try to fill up particular colours to prevent the other player from claiming that colour.  The game ends when one player fills their side of the chart.  The the winner is the player with the highest total score.  Somewhat similar to Yahtzee.

Contents: 
4 Dice
Instructions
Pad of scoring charts.

Name: Bible Picture Lotto
Description:
Bible Picture Lotto

This is a vintage (1950s era?) religion game.

"Learn Bible stories while you play"

Ages 5 - 10

"Beautiful full-color picture cards with over forty illustrations"

"Six Bible stories"

Includes 6 large picture boards and 36 small picture cards. The boards represent Bible characters like Daniel, Moses, Joseph, etc.

The cards feature objects from the Biblical character's life (Daniel/Lion, etc.) and players match the cards to the correct Bible story.

Warner Press No. T3841

Name: BIG FISH little fish "The GREATER than less than GAME"
Description:
BIG FISH little fish is a comparing whole numbers game for Kindergarten through 2nd Grade.

BIG FISH little fish is designed to reinforce basic critical thinking skills by comparing whole numbers and co-operation skills by having Players make correct comparisons.

BIG FISH little fish:

44 Number cards
1 Spinner

2 ways to win:

"Everyone is a Winner” - The game is over when each Player has played all their cards.

“Individual Winner” - The game is over when the first Player has played all their cards.

Name: Mini Zitternix
Description: Wooden dowels of the same thickness are placed within a wooden ring and then twisted so they balance on the table. Players roll a colored die which determines which dowel they must remove from the ring (colors are green, orange, and blue). Each dowel is worth 1 point. The player with the most points when the structure collapses (when the ring hits the table) is the winner.

Name: The Greatest Adventure: Stories from the Bible – Moses
Description:
"Journey with Moses as he frees his people from slavery."

"This fun and easy game is intended to help understand the stories, events, and people in the Bible with questions and answers."

"Each player in turn reads a question card. The player turns over the question card to see if the question was answered correctly. If correct, the player moves forward on the game path the same number of spaces indicated on the card."

No spinners or dice are used.

Name: Kingdoms of the Middle Sea
Description:
Each player takes on the management of an independent kingdom that has its capital on one of the four continents surrounding the Middle Sea. Using military power, economic might and religious influence players vie to increase the size of their kingdoms. Players must also guard against unrest, which could cause rebellion or even civil war to break out. With several paths to victory, players may choose peaceful economic expansion, military invasion, religious unrest or a combination of all three to defeat their rivals.

The requires one piecepack, a box of kitchen matches or small wooden/plastic rods to represent goods, roads and ports and about fifty pennies (or tokens) to represent gold.

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Kubus Fidibus
Description:
from the rules:
"Bobby Butterfingers pulls at his wizard’s coat. This time he must not spoil his magician’s exam. Slowly and carefully, he takes the big magic cube from the pedestal. 'Now, how did that correct spell go?'. Then he remembers. With a firm voice he shouts 'Butterfingers Cube', takes his magic ring and lets it skillfully fall into the cube. The other apprentices hold their breath - if nothing falls out of the cube, Bobby will pass the test.

Whoever can hold the magic cube with a steady hand and skillfully let the objects fall inside, will be left at the end of the game with the fewest objects in front of them."
